scopecontent.head: Scope and Content Information
scopecontent.p: The collection contains two manuscripts: "To Harry Munroe," and an untitled essay on Greek and Italian brigandage.

Letters discuss her health, the weather, her writing including "Fairy Fingers" and "Mimic Life," Elizabeth H. Appleton, Thomas Crawford, Catherine Hayes, Mary Morris Hamilton Schuyler and the Mount Vernon Ladies' Association, Ion Perdicaris, William Foushee Ritchie, Randolph Rogers, Frank Slayton, Julia G. O. Smyth, and Henry Alexander Wise.

did.unittitle: "Greek and Italian Brigandage is a subject of almost as much interest in England as in Italy and Greece . . ." n.d.
Anna Cora [Ogden] Mowatt [Ritchie], New York, to James T[homas]Fields 1842 Sep 23

scopecontent.p: Discusses in detail: her desire for his help in publishing "a moral tale for the young" under a pseudonym. Mentions: Edwin Percy Whipple, Boston, William Davis Ticknor, and New World.

did.unittitle: A[nna]C[ora Ogden]Mowatt [Ritchie], Greenfield Hill, CT, to Catharine O Sargent, Boston, MA 184[6] Jul 23

scopecontent.p: Discusses in detail: Julia Gabriella Ogden and her fiance Joseph Kennedy Smyth. Mentions: Samuel Gouverneur Ogden, Julia Fairlie Ogden, Typeeby Herman Melville, and Lizzy.

did.unittitle: [Anna Cora Ogden] Mowatt [Ritchie], Boston, MA, to Mr. Campbell 1852 May 31

scopecontent.p: Discusses briefly Mr. Campbell's having most of her published works.

did.unittitle: Anna Cora [Ogden] Mowatt Ritchie, Richmond, VA, to Harper and Brothers, New York 1858 Feb

scopecontent.p: Discusses Elizabeth Haven Appleton, on whose behalf she is submitting a manuscript. Mentions Cincinnati, OH, and Harper's New Monthly Magazine.

did.unittitle: Anna Cora [Ogden] Mowatt Ritchie, Astoria, to S[amuel] B[ulkley]Ruggles 1858 Aug 25

scopecontent.p: Discusses in detail support for Mary Morris Hamilton Schuyler's organization for fund-raising for Mount Vernon Discusses briefly: Louise Ingersoll Greenough; her desire to see Ruggles; Mary Rutledge Fogg; Octavia Walton LeVert; the coincidence of the landing of the transatlantic telegraph cable and the first use of steam towage on a canal being on the same day. Mentions: Boston, Enquirer, Samuel Gouverneur Ogden, New York, Tennessee, Alabama, and Edward Everett.
